Appendix B Impact of fiducial cosmology

Our method requires the use of a fiducial cosmology, both for defining the comoving coordinate grid on which the correlations are computed, and for the template power spectrum that is used to construct the theoretical model for the LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ correlations. This fiducial cosmology is based on cosmic microwave background anisotropy data from the Planck satellite (Planck Collaboration etÂ al., 2016). In this appendix, we test the impact of this choice of fiducial cosmology.

We recompute the LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ auto and cross-correlations of one of the mocks using two different values of the matter density parameter, Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m}. The two values are Î©m=0.27subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.27\Omega_{m}=0.27 and Î©m=0.36subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.36\Omega_{m}=0.36. We then perform our standard analysis and measure Î±psubscriptğ›¼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}Â and Ï•fsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘“\phi_{f}, but we use different power spectrum templates to keep the fiducial Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m} value consistent in each analysis. In order to compare the results, we compute the relevant combinations of distances as derived parameters. Following Cuceu etÂ al. (2021), measurements of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and Î±psubscriptğ›¼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}Â correspond to:

We compare the results for the large and small values of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m} with the one obtained from our standard analysis (using Î©m=0.315subscriptÎ©ğ‘š0.315\Omega_{m}=0.315) in Figure 8. All three results give consistent measurements, however, they are not identical. This can be attributed to the fact that pixel pairs are distributed to different bins in the correlation when using different values of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m}, because the comoving distances change. This will have an impact on the measured parameters, especially for BAO, where small changes in the correlation measurements (consistent with the expected noise) can produce large changes in the shape of the posterior (e.g. Cuceu etÂ al., 2020). Furthermore, when changing the fiducial Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m}, the smallest scale that we fit will be different for the same rminsubscriptğ‘Ÿminr_{\mathrm{min}}. For example, the smaller value of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m} leads to smaller scales being assigned larger comoving separations. This is why the size of the constraints increases as Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m} increases.202020This also means that our choice of rmin=25subscriptğ‘Ÿmin25r_{\mathrm{min}}=25Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}Â is based on the Planck cosmology. Therefore, the analysis should be re-done, and a new minimum scale chosen, if we had reason to believe the real cosmology was very different from the one inferred by Planck. Nevertheless, all three results are consistent with each other even for these extreme values of Î©msubscriptÎ©ğ‘š\Omega_{m}.

Appendix C Other scale cuts

In SectionÂ 3.2 we have focused on the minimum scale fitted, rminsubscriptğ‘Ÿminr_{\mathrm{min}}. However, we also have to choose the largest scale we fit for, rmaxsubscriptğ‘Ÿmaxr_{\mathrm{max}}. Furthermore, as our measurement is two-dimensional, we could also impose different scale cuts along or across the line-of-sight. We tested different versions of this analysis, which we summarize here.

We show the impact of changing the largest separation included in our fit, rmaxsubscriptğ‘Ÿmaxr_{\mathrm{max}}, in Figure 9. We perform the same type of comparison as we did for rminsubscriptğ‘Ÿminr_{\mathrm{min}} in Figure 5. The scales we tested range from 140140140Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}Â to 200200200Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}. We find that measurements of Ï•fsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘“\phi_{f}Â are unbiased for all the rmaxsubscriptğ‘Ÿmaxr_{\mathrm{max}} values we have tried. Furthermore, the improvement in the constraint as we include more data is very weak. Therefore, following eBOSS, we decided to choose rmax=180subscriptğ‘Ÿmax180r_{\mathrm{max}}=180Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}Â in our standard analysis.

As most of the contaminants of the LyÎ±ğ›¼\alpha forestÂ correlation functions have their largest impact along the line-of-sight, we also decided to test a cut in râŠ¥minsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿbottomminr_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}. This is the smallest transverse scale that we fit, and values râŠ¥min>0superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿbottommin0r_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}>0Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}Â mean that we are removing the columns in the correlation that lie along the line-of-sight. The systematic error and expected statistical constraint on Ï•fsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘“\phi_{f}Â for different values of râŠ¥minsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿbottomminr_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}} are show in Figure 10. We find that removing the first correlation column along the line-of-sight (râŠ¥min=4superscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿbottommin4r_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}=4Â hâˆ’1â€‹Mpcsuperscriptâ„1Mpch^{-1}\text{Mpc}) still results in an unbiased measurement. However, removing more data after that starts to introduce a significant systematic bias.212121Note that we are plotting the absolute value of Î”â€‹Ï•Î”italic-Ï•\Delta\phi. Therefore, the trend of increasing systematic bias in Figure 10 does not mean the bias is all in the same direction. This could be explained by the fact that removing the columns along the line-of-sight is degrading our ability to fit the parameters that control the contaminants (e.g. HCDs and metals). Even though these contaminants have their strongest impact along the line-of-sight, they have a small impact on the correlation even at large transverse separations. Therefore, it is still important to model them accurately. Given these results, we chose to not impose any cut in râŠ¥minsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘Ÿbottomminr_{\bot}^{\mathrm{min}}.

Appendix D Population constraints

As described in SectionÂ 3.4, when running the analysis on each of the one hundred mocks, we are restricted to using a minimizer due to computational constraints. This means that the reported constraints on the measured parameters are just estimates due to two reasons. Firstly, they assume the posterior is Gaussian around the best fitting value. Secondly, the best fit for the parameters of interest (Ï•fsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘“\phi_{f}, Î±psubscriptğ›¼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}) is found without properly marginalizing over the nuisance parameters.222222The best fit value of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â reported by the minimizer is conditional on the best fitting values of all the nuisance parameters. However, in the Bayesian framework, the quantity we are interested in is the value of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â conditional on the posterior distributions of the nuisance parameters. Only in the second case is the uncertainty due to these parameters properly taken into account. While these approximations might be correct for the BAO parameters due to their lack of correlations with the nuisance parameters (Cuceu etÂ al., 2020), Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â definitely has such correlations (Appendix E). Therefore, in order to study accurate parameter constraints from the population of mocks, we need to use a sampler.

For the purposes of this appendix, we ran the sampler on correlations computed only using the LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ region (no LyÎ²ğ›½\betaÂ region) from uncontaminated synthetic data sets. These mocks do not include the effects of HCDs, metal absorption or redshift errors (they are also described in du Mas des Bourboux etÂ al., 2020). Therefore, the parameter space is much smaller, allowing for the computation of the full posterior distributions using a sampler. We performed the joint analysis of the auto and cross-correlations for all one hundred uncontaminated mocks.

In Figure 11, we show histograms of the constraints on Î±psubscriptğ›¼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}, Ï•psubscriptitalic-Ï•p\phi_{\mathrm{p}}, and Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â from the population of one hundred mocks. The main result is the one given by the sampler, in blue. We also plot the standard deviation of the best fitting values for each of the parameters over the population of mocks. This shows that the variance of the parameter values obtained from the one hundred realizations is consistent with the measured uncertainty in individual realizations, which means the uncertainties are properly accounted for.

We also compare results from the sampler with the estimates from the minimizer in Figure 11. While they roughly agree for the BAO parameters (Î±psubscriptğ›¼p\alpha_{\mathrm{p}}Â and Ï•psubscriptitalic-Ï•p\phi_{\mathrm{p}}), this is not the case for Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}. The two give different constraints, as shown by the difference between the red and blue histograms. This is not surprising given the assumptions involved in the fitter constraints. However, the variance of the Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â best fits is also different between the two (the red and blue vertical lines). This means that marginalization over the nuisance parameters is important in this case.232323In a frequentist framework, a possible solution for this would be to use these results to compute non-Gaussian Î”â€‹Ï‡2Î”superscriptğœ’2\Delta\chi^{2} values in order to set more accurate confidence intervals on Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}.

While this has been a rough test due to computational constraints, most of the parameters that Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â is correlated with are still present in uncontaminated mocks (bLyâ€‹Î±subscriptğ‘Lyğ›¼b_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha}, Î²Lyâ€‹Î±subscriptğ›½Lyğ›¼\beta_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha} and Î²QSOsubscriptğ›½QSO\beta_{\mathrm{QSO}}). The main omission is bHCDsubscriptğ‘HCDb_{\mathrm{HCD}}. Therefore, it would be interesting to perform this analysis with the effect of HCDs modelled in the mocks. Alternatively, future studies should perform the analysis on the fully contaminated mocks if there is access to enough computational resources.

Appendix E Parameter correlations

The advantage of BAO analyses is that they measure a well-defined feature in the correlation function. BAO scale parameters rarely have any significant correlations with the nuisance parameters, which means they are much more robust to different analysis choices when it comes to modelling contaminants. On the other hand, full-shape analyses rely on the ability to accurately model correlation functions over all the scales of interest. We have already shown in Figure 6 what biases are introduced when not modelling certain contaminants. In this appendix, we go into more detail on the sensitivity of Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â measurements to other nuisance parameters.

In Figure 12 we show the posterior distributions of the main parameters that are correlated with Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}. The two posteriors are from the fit to the two LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ auto-correlations, and from the joint fit of all four correlations. The cross-correlations between LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ and quasars cannot be included in such a comparison because the full system of parameters is degenerate.242424See SectionÂ 3.1 above and Section 4 of Cuceu etÂ al. (2021) The most important correlations are between Ï•ssubscriptitalic-Ï•s\phi_{\mathrm{s}}Â and the LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ bias and RSD parameters, bLyâ€‹Î±subscriptğ‘Lyğ›¼b_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha} and Î²Lyâ€‹Î±subscriptğ›½Lyğ›¼\beta_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha}. These two are highly correlated between themselves and with the HCD bias, bHCDsubscriptğ‘HCDb_{\mathrm{HCD}}. The LyÎ±ğ›¼\alphaÂ auto-correlation provides most of the information on these parameters. On the other hand, the information on Î²QSOsubscriptğ›½QSO\beta_{\mathrm{QSO}} comes from the LyÎ±ğ›¼\alpha-QSO cross-correlation. However, a measurement of Î²Lyâ€‹Î±subscriptğ›½Lyğ›¼\beta_{\mathrm{Ly}\alpha} (from the auto) is necessary to constrain it due to their degeneracy in the model of the cross-correlation. While we treat Î²QSOsubscriptğ›½QSO\beta_{\mathrm{QSO}} as a nuisance parameter in this work, future studies could also attempt to extract a measurement of the growth rate of structure from it.
